ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The course needs more structure. It covers too many topics.

Class could have been done as a half-semester class. Case assignments were beyond vague, instructor put no work into preparing them or he didn't know what he wanted out them or the students in general.

The course needs more content and structure. The non slide deck style will be fine for one or two lectures, but a whole semester with repetition, lack of plans, lack of categorization or classification. It did not help me particularly in learning much, through first half of the semester, and then I decide to change it to audit status rather than credit. Given that the content is not super high, instructor can also explore options of offering it as a half semester course.

Group work, in general, is a great way to learn material. However, I felt the instructor did not do his part to lecture enough. I personally find lectures boring, but there really needed to be more. When doing cases, all my team members and I realized that we did not learn sufficiently learn enough from class sessions to apply any usable knowledge to the assignments. I think the instructor tried to get students to realize that coming up with sustainability metrics is very difficult. After the first case, the point was clear. I wish there were smaller assignments or cases that we could read and discuss in class, particularly historical cases in which we knew what decisions or pathways companies had made or taken.

I think the class was great. My only suggestion would be to spread out more the assignments so that they don't stack up at the end of the semester when things get crazy and you don't have time to dedicate to all the assignments.

Concepts were not clearly explained and not so organized. In the first month students struggled understanding what the course was truly about. There was often a disconnect between the key concepts taught and the assignments. Students would have benefited more from the assignment if the instructor had provided his solution to the assignments.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: I liked that the cases were real-world problems and were based on real companies and their concerns. I also enjoyed the guest speakers, especially NS
External guest speakers
Broad overview
The (group) case assignments and the hands-on approach to the classes with a lot of questions and scenarios, which was really interesting.
The fact that we at least heard about about some corporate sustainability metrics.
Todd - he is amazing!!!! PATIENT !!! Group break out sessions in class - learned so much from these.
Very hands-on and real-life practicalities

The best aspect of this course for me was the opportunity to do a lot of group work with people from somewhat diverse backgrounds and skill sets. This helped to develop my teamwork skills and find ways to quickly assess the knowledge/ideas at the table and efficiently translate them into a finished product.
Outside speakers brought great value to the course. Todd is also a great resource for students.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I didn't feel like we got taught enough. A lot of the learning centered around "figure it out as you go" in the homework assignments, but most of us seemed to yearn for a little bit more guidance on HOW to design good metrics
Structure and depth

The equal distribution of assignments during the semester (too much at the end), and perhaps improved communication about the different sections and structure of the course overall (it sometimes seemed very ad-hoc with speakers showing up or not - that's fine and understandable, as long as the overall structure and different parts are clear over the course of the semester). Perhaps the lecturer should also have a bit more 'confidence' instead of coming across as unprepared - even though that was not the case it does take away some authority which is not always desirable.
Structure was severely lacking. The Instructor does not know what to do with this class.

The instructor needs to teach during lectures. Having group sessions is a lazy way out of teaching. Instructor could have done his "homework" to learn material/prep for lectures--it really showed in class.
The homework is often too broad and maybe mandatory readings and field trips would help

Two aspects of this course were problematic for me. The first was that I felt the class sessions relied too heavily on guest speakers and not enough on reading and discussion of literature on the topic of CSR. Although we had the opportunity to do some of these readings, they were not emphasized in class and most people did not do them. I felt that the guest lectures, taken as a whole, were disparate and not intellectually rigorous enough to stimulate very memorable discussions on the topics of this class. The second aspect was the case study assignments. Many of them were repetitive in nature and I did not feel that I benefitted much after the second case study. Furthermore, doing three back-to-back case studies at the end of the semester during finals further degraded the value of the case studies for me, although this had more to do with scheduling.
Structure and concepts
More structure to the course

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There were no discussion sections.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Very good for focus on corporate sustainability and (overview of) quantitative measurements behind that.
On paper it should fit in perfectly, in practice I just learned you can make a metric out of anything to make your case for whatever you want to make your case for.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To improve my proficiency in quantitative methods supporting business and sustainability rationales.
I was hoping to learn what metrics corporations use, why they use them and how. basically i wanted to learn what corporate sustainability departments actually do.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes.
No.
Unfortunately no

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: free-rider problem, difficult to deal with and find balance

The group cases felt like we didn't have enough direction or guidance on what we should be doing, especially what the assignment was asking for. Also, the last two assignments felt very rushed. They could have been better spread out throughout the semester.

Advantages: was great to get to know fellow students, learned a lot from the interaction Disadvantages: because of prominence of group work there was little incentive to engage individually with the material, which sometimes created a poor discussion environment because we hadn't all prepared adequately. Unclear assignments may have contributed to a LOT of confusion and stress within groups and overworking to then underdeliver. As a result I'm not sure we captured the key messages we were supposed to from the assignments
Disadvantage - timing for brainstorming session Advantage - learn from others
Learn from each other and collaborate between F&ES and SOM.
Group work was definitely suitable but pointless as the cases were so vague the groups never knew what to do.

Learn a lot from the experiences of students with varying degrees of experience and degree backgrounds. Gave me confidence in what I "brought to the table." these interactions highlighted the value of it.

This class was based on group work and it was very challenging. Team mates had different opinions and views about the topic and it was hard to coordinate so many group projects with so many different people. The advantage is that you don't have to do all the work alone and can learn from your group. But, I would say it was more of a negative experience than positive.
Through the work group I improved my skills at working under deadlines with people of different backgrounds and disciplines.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: This class isn't quite the how to manual you might be expecting. It's much more theoretical and case-by-case based, and might be frustrating if you're expecting to get clear guidance on how to create metrics or measure sustainability performance. However, it does give you good exposure to cases and business problems.
Find a good group that will push you and learn along with you, as almost everything in this course depends on the group
Don't take the course unless the Instructor puts some thought into restructuring it.
TAKE IT!!!!!
